You may observe, up and down, in the Courts of Princes, certain Animals; some of them Trick'd up with Feathers: Others, in White, Russet, Ash Colour'd Frocks▪ Gowns, Habits: Or call 'em what you will, These are the Instruments, you must know, that are still Irritating Kings to the Thirst of War, and Blood, under the splendid Notion of Empire, and Glory: And with the same Art, and Industry, they enflame the Spirits of the Nobility likewise, and of the Common-People. Their Sermons are only Harangues, in honour of the out-rages of Fire and Sword, under the Character of a Iust, a Religious, or a Holy War. And,
which is yet more Wonderful; they make it to be Gods Cause, on Both sides. God Fights for us, is the cry of the French Pulpits: And (what have they to fear, that have the Lord of Hosts for their Protector?) Acquit your selves like Men say the English, and the Spaniard, and the Victory is Certain: For (This is God Cause, not Caesars.) As for those that fall in the Battle, their Souls mount as directly to Heaven, as if they had Wings to carry 'em thither. (Arms and all.)

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: But do their Disciples believe all this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You cannot imagine the Power of a Well dissembled Religion; where there's Youth, Ignorance, Ambition, and a natural Animosity, to work upon. 'Tis an easie matter to Impose, where there is a Previous Propension to be Deceiv'd!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Oh, that it did but lie in my Power to do these People a good Office!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Give 'em a Magnificent Treat then; there's nothing they'l take better.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: It must be of Mallows, Lupines, and Leeks, then, for we have nothing else you know.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray let it be Patridge, Capons, Pheasant, they'l never think they'r welcome else.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: But to the point, what should set these People so much a Gog upon Sedition, and Broyles? What can they get by't?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Do not you know then, that they get more by the Dead, then by the Living? Why, there are Testaments, Funerals, Bulls, and Twenty other pretty Perquisites that are worth the looking after: Besides that a Camp-Life agrees much better with their Humour, then to lie droneing in their Cells. War breeds Bishops, and a very Block-Head, in a Time of Peace, comes many times to make an Excellent Military Prelate.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Well! They understand their business.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Stay: But to the matter of a Boat; what necessity of having another?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis but Swiming once again, instead of Rowing.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Well, but now I think on't; how came the Boat
to sink?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Under the Weight of the Passengers

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I thought you had carry'd Shadows only, not Bodies. What may be the Weight, I prethee, of a Cargo of Ghosts?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Why, let 'em be as Light as Water-Spiders, there may be enow of them to do a bodies Work. But then my Vessel is a kind of a Phantome too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have seen the time, when you had as many Ghosts as you could Stow a-Bord; and Three or Four Thousand more hanging at the Stern, and your Barque me thought never so much as felt on't.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: That is all according as the Ghosts are: For your Hectical, phthisical Souls, that go-off in a Consumption, weigh little or nothing. But those that are Torn out of Bodies, in a Habit of Foul Humours; as in Apoplexyes, Quinzies, Fevers, and the like: But most of all, in the Chance of War: These, I must tell ye, carry a great deal of Corpulent, and gross matter, along with them.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: As for the Spaniards, and the French, methinks they should not be very Heavy.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: No nor comparatively with Others: And yet I do not find them altogether so Light as Feathers, neither. But for the Brittains, and the Germans, that are rank Feeders, I had only Ten of 'em a-Bord once, and if I had not Lighten'd my Boat of part of my Lading, we had all gone to the Bottom.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You were hard put to't I find.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay, but what do ye think, when we are Pester'd with Great Lords, Hectors and Bu • lies?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You were speaking of a Iust War, e'en now. You have nothing to do, I presume with those that fall in such a War: These go to rights, all to Heaven, they say.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p:
Whither they go, I know not; but this I'm sure of; Let the War be what it will, it sends us such sholes of Cripples, that a body would think there were not one Soul more left above ground; and they come over-charg'd,
not only with Gut, and Surfeits, but with Patents, Pardons, Commissions, and I know not how much Lumber besides.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Do they not come Naked to the Ferry then?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Yes, yes; but at their first coming they are strangely haunted with the Dreams of all these things.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Are Dreams so Heavy then?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Heavy, d'ye say? Why they have Drown'd my Boat already: And then there's the Weight of so many Halfe-pence, over and above.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: That's somewhat I must confess, if they be Brass.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Well, well! It behoves me at a venture to get a stout Vessel.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Without many Words; upon the main, thou'rt a happy Man.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Wherein, as thou lov'st me?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Thou't get thee an Aldermans Estate, in the turning of a Hand.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: There must be a World of Fares, at a Half-penny a Ghost, for a man to thrive upon't.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You'l have enough I warrant ye, to do your business.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'Twould mount to somewhat indeed, if they'd bring their Wealth along with them. But they come to me, Weeping and Wailing, for the Kingdoms, the Dignities, the Abbies, and the Treasure that they have left behind 'em; pay their bare Passage and that's all. So that what I have been these three Thousand years a scraping together, must go all away at a swoop, upon one Boat.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: He that would Get Mony, must Venture Mony.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay; but the People in the World have better Trading they say: Where a Man in three Years time shall make himself a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and Squander't away again, perhaps in half the time. Your gain 'tis true, is less, but then 'tis steady and surer.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Not so steady neither, perchance. For what if some Providence should dispose the Hearts of Princes to a General Peace: My Work's at an end.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
My life for
yours, there's no fear of that, for One-half-Score Year. The Pope is Labouring it, I know: But he had as good keep his Breath to Cool • his Porridg. Not but that there is Notable Muttering and Grumbling every where? 'Tis an unreasonable thing they cry, that Christendom should be Torn to pieces thus, to gratifie a particular Picque, or the Ambition of two or three Swaggering pretenders. People, in fine, are grown Sick of these Hurly-Burlies: But when Men are bewitch'd once, there's no place left for better Counsels. Now to the business of the Boat. We have Workmen among our selves, without need to look any further. As Vulcan, for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Right: If it were for an Iron, or a Brazen Vessel.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Or 'twill Cost but a small matter, to send for a Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Well! And where shall we have Materials?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Why, certainly you have Timber enough.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: The woods that were in Elyzium, are all destroy'd: Not so much as a stick left.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How so, I beseech ye!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: With burning Hereticks Ghosts. And now, for want of other Fewel, we are fain to Dig for Cole.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But these Ghosts methinks might have been punish'd cheaper.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Rhadamanthus (the Judge) would have it so.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And what will you do now, for your Wherry and Oars?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: I'll look to the Helm my self, and if the Ghosts will not row, let 'em e'en stay behind.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And what shall They do, that ne're serv'd to the Trade?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Serve or not serve: 'Tis all a case to me; For I make Monarchs Row, and Cardinals Row, as well as Porters, and Carmen. They all take their Turns, without any Priviledg or Exception.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well! I wish you a Boat to your mind, and so I'll away to Hell with my good News, and leave ye. But Hark ye first.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Speak then.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Make wha •
hast you can, or you'll be Smother'd in the Crow'd.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Nay, you will find at least two Hundred Thousand upon the Bank already, besides those that are Plung'd into the Lake. I'll make all the dispatch I can, and pray'e let them know I'm coming.

div.head: THE OLD MANS DIALOGUE.
COL. XXII.

argument.p: A Short View of Humane Life; in a Colloquie betwixt Four Old Men of several Humours. The first a Man of Sobriety, and Government. The second a Debauchèe. The third, a Rambling Bigott. The fourth, a Man truly Religious.

div.stage: EUSEBIUS, PAMPYRUS, POLYGAMUS, GLYCION; HUGONITIO, HENRICUS, WAGONERS.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
WHat new Faces have we here? Stay a little. Either my Memory, and my Spectacles abuse me, or that must be Pampyrus; To'ther Polygamus; and the third, Glycion; my Old acquaintances and Companions. They are
certainly the very same.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Friend, what dost thou stand staring at with thy Glass-Eyes, as if thou would'st bewitch People: Pray come nearer a little.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: In good time, honest Eusebius; how glad am I to see thee!

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: All Health and Happiness be to the best of Men.

sp.speaker: Et.
sp.p: One blessing upon you altogether, my dear Friends. What providence; or at least what providential chance has brought us together now! 'Tis Forty Year, I believe, since we Four saw one another. Why 'tis as if some Mercurial Rod had brought us into a Circle with a Charm. But what are ye doing here?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: We are sitting.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I know you are. But what for, I beseech ye?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: We wait for the Antwerp-Wagon.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You are going to the Fayre, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: We are so: But rather upon Curiosity, then business. Though some go for one, some for t'other.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Well! and I am going thither my self too: But what do ye stay for?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Only to Bargain for our Passage.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: These Waggoners are a Dogged sort of People. But what if we should put a Sham upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: With all my Heart, if it might be fairly done.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: If they will not come to reasonable Terms, I'm for telling them, that wee'l e'en Trudge it away a Foot?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: You may as well tell 'em that you'l flie thither, as that you'l walk it; and they'l believe it as soon.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Shall I advise you for the best now?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Ay, by all means.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: You may be sure they are at their Brandy; and the longer they Fuddle, the more danger of Over-turning.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: You must rise betimes to find a Fore-man Sober.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: I phansie it would be worth the while, for us Four to take a Wagon to our selves, 'tis but a little more charge, and we shall get the sooner thither: We shall have the more Room, and the greater Freedom of Conversation.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Glycion is much in the Right on't. For
good Company upon the way does the Office of a Coach, and makes the Journey both Easie and Pleasant, besides the lib • rty of Discourse.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Come good People, I have taken the Wagon; Let's up and be Jogging. So. And now I begin to live methinks, in the sight of so many of my Antient Friends, and Camarades; and after so long a separation.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And I, to grow young again.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: How long may't be, since we Four were in Pension together at Paris?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I take it to be a matter of Two and Forty Years.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And were not we Four much of an Age? Then.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Very near the matter.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And what a difference does there seem to be at present! Here's Glycion, has nothing of an Old Man about him: And for Polygamus, there; a Body would take him for his Grand-Father.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: The thing is manifestly true. But what should be the reason on't?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why either the One stopt in his Course, or the Other made more hast then Good speed.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: No, no. Men may Slacken their Pace, but Time Rowles on without respect.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Come Glycion, deal frankly with us, and say; How many Years hast thou upon thy Back?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: More then Ducats in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: But the Number, I prethee.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Just Sixty Six.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Why thou't never be Old.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Well; But by what Secret Arts hast thou preserv'd thy self in Health and Youth, so long; without either Gray Hairs, or Wrinkles? There's Fire and Spirit in your Eyes: Your Teeth are White and Even, a fresh Colour, and a smooth Plump Habit of Body.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Upon condition that you tell me, how you came to be Old so soon, I'le tell you how I kept my self Young so long.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I'll do't with all my Heart; and therefore begin the History, at your leaving of Paris.

sp.speaker: GLYCION.
sp.p:
I went directly into my own Country; and by that time I had been there about a year,
I began to bethink my self, what Course of Life to chuse, as a matter of great importance toward my future Peace. And so I cast my thoughts upon several Examples, good and bad; some that succeeded, others that miscarry'd.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: This was a point of Prudence more then I expected; for you had none of these sober Considerations about ye, when I knew you at Paris.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: That was before I had sow'd my wild Oats, as we say. But you must know, my good Friend, that I did not do all this neither, purely by my own Mother Wit.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I was indeed a little surpriz'd at it.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: The Course I took, was, in short this. The first thing I did was to find out a Person of the most general Reputation, for Gravity, Wisdom, and long Experience in the whole Neighbourhood: and one that in my own Opinion was the happiest of Men.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Very discreetly done.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: This Man I made my Friend and my Councellor; and by his Advice, I Marry'd a Wife.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: With a fair Portion, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gl.
Po.
sp.p: What was your Age then?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Toward Two and Twenty.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: A happy Creature!

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: You must not take this yet to be wholly the Work of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Il'e shew ye now. 'Tis the Practice of the World, to Love before they Iudge, but I Iudg'd before I Lov'd. Not but that I took this Woman more for Posterity sake, then for any Carnal satisfaction: And never a happier Couple under the Sun, for the eight years, that we lived together, but then I lost her.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Had you no Children by her?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Yes, Four; that, God be prais'd for't, are yet alive: two Boys, and two Girls.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: And what's your Condition at present? Private, or Publick?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p:
Why I have a publick Commission. It might have been better,
but there's Credit enough in't to secure me from Contempt, and then 'tis free from vexatious Attendances: which is as much as I ask; so long as I have sufficient for my self, and somewhat upon occasion, to spare for my Friend; which is the very height of my Ambition. And then I have taken care to give more Reputation to my Office, then I have received from it. I hope I have done well in't.

sp.speaker: P • .
sp.p: Without all Controversie.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: At this rate of Government my Life has been long and easie to me, and I am grown old in the Arms and good esteem of all my Companions, and Friends.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: But there's a hard saying methinks, though very much to the Purpose: He that has no Enemies, has no Friends. Envy never fayls to tread upon the Heel of Happiness.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p:
Right, if it be a splendid, pompous Felicity: But in a state of Mediocrity, a Man's quiet and safe. I have made it my perpetual Care and study, never to raise any advantage to my self, from the Miseries, or misfortunes of other people. I have kept as much as possible▪ from the cumber of business, especially from invidious Employments, that could not be discharg'd without making many Enemies. Nay, as near as I can, I would not disoblige one man to help another. In case of any misunderstanding, I do what I can, either to excuse and soften it, or to let it fall, without taking notice of it; or else, with good Offices to set all Right again. I never lov'd Squabbling and Contention; but where there's no avoiding it, I chuse rather to lose my Money then my Friend, upon the whole, I am for Mitio's Character in the Comedy. I affront no man; I carry a chearful Countenance to all. I salute, or resalute, with Heart and Good-will: I cross no mans Inclination: I censure no mans purposes or doings; I am not so Self-conceited, as to despise
other people, and it never moves me, when I see men over-value themselves. That which I would have kept secret, I tell to no Mortal. I never was curious into the Privacies of other Men; and if any thing of that Nature came to my knowledge, I never blab'd it. 'Tis my constant Practice, either to say nothing at all of the Absent, or to speak of them with kindness and respect: For half the Quarrels in the World take their Rise from the intemperance of the Tongue. I have made it my Rule, never to provoke Differences, or to heed them: but on the contrary, so much as in me lay, either to moderate, or to extinguish them. By these means I have kept clear of Envy, and secur'd my self of the Affection and Esteem of my Country-men.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Did not you find a single Life Irksome to you?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: The sharpest Affliction that ever befel me, was the death of my Wife, I could not but passionately wish that we might have grown Old together, and have continued happy in the enjoyment of the common Blessing of our Children: but since Providence had otherwise determin'd, Duty and Religion told me, that Gods way was best for both, and that it would be both foolish, and wicked to torment my self in vain, without any advantage either to the Dead, or to the Living.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: You were so happy in one Wife, methinks it should have tempted you to venture upon another.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: I had some thoughts that way: but as I Married one for the hopes of Children, so for these Childrens sakes, I resolv'd never to Marry again.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: But were not the Nights tedious to ye without a Bed-fellow?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p:
Nothing is hard to a willing mind. And then do but consider the benefits of a single Life. There are a sort of people in the World, that will be still making the worst of every thing, and taking it by the wrong Handle. As Crates, (or
some body else, in an Epigram under his Name) has summ'd up the Evils or Inconveniences of humane Life. And the Resolution is this: That it is best not to be born. Now that Humour of Metrodorus pleases me a great deal better, in his Abstract of the Blessings of Life. 'Tis a more comfortable Prospect, and it sweetens the Disgusts, and weaknesses of Flesh and Blood. For my own part, I have brought my self to such a Temper of indifference, as never to be transported with any violent Inclinations or Aversions: and this secures me, whether my Fortune be good or bad, from either Insolence in one Case, or Abjection or despondence in the other.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Make this good, and you are a greater Philosopher then either Thales, or Metrodorus themselves.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: So soon as ever I find but the first Motion of any disorder in my mind, (as these Touches are not to be avoided) whether it be from the sense of an Indignity or Affront, I cast it immediately out of my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Well! but there are some Family-Provocations, and Offences for the purpose, that would anger a Saint.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: They never stay long enough with me, to make an Impression. If I can quiet things, I do't: If I cannot, I say thus to my self: Why should I gall my self, to no manner of purpose? In a word, my Reason does that for me at first, which after a little while, time it self would do: briefly, If any thing troubles me, I never carry the thought on't to Bed with me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: 'Tis no wonder to see so vigorous a Body, under the Government of so virtuous a mind.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p:
Come, come Gentlemen; in the Freedom of Friendship. I have kept this Guard upon my self: not to do any thing that might reflect upon my own Honour, or my Families. There's no Misery like that of a Guilty Conscience: and I never lay my Head upon my Pillow at night, till I have by Repentance reconcil'd
my self to God, for the Transgressions of the day past. He that's well with his Maker, can never be uneasie within himself: for the Love and Protection of the Almighty supports him against all the Malice of wicked Men,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Have you never any anxious thoughts upon the apprehension of Death?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: No more then I have for looking back upon the Day of my Birth. I know I must dye, and to live in fear on't, may possibly shorten my Life, it can never lengthen it, so that my only Care is to live honestly and comfortably, and leave the rest to Providence. No man can live Happily, that does not live Well.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: But to live so long in the same Place, though 'twere in Rome it self: I should grow Grey, I Phancy, with so much of the same thing over again.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: There's Pleasure no doubt on't, in Variety; but then for long Travels, though experience and observation may make men Wise, they run the Risk of a thousand Dangers, to ballance that Prudence. Now I am for the safer way of Compassing the World in a Map, and I can find out more in Printed Travels, then ever Vlysses saw in all his twenty years Ramble. I have my self a Villa, some two miles out of Town: when I'm There, I'm a Country-man; and when I come back again, I am welcom'd, as if I had been upon the discovery of the North-West passage.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You keep your Body in order, I presume with Physick.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: No, no, I have nothing to do with the Doctors, I was never Let-blood in my Life yet: and never medled with either Pill or Potion. When I feel my self any way indisposed; change of Air, or a spare Diet, sets me right again.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Don't you Study sometime?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p:
Oh by all means, 'Tis the most agreeable Entertainment of my Life. But not so, as to make a Toyl of a Pleasure. And I do it not for Ostentation, but for the Love and Delight of
it, or for the informing of my Life and Manners •
After Dinner I have a Collation of edifying Discourse or Stories, or else some-body to Read to me; and I never Plod at my Book above an hour at a time. When that's over, I take my Lute perhaps, and a walk in my Chamber, either Groping it or Singing to't; or ruminating it may be, upon what I have heard or read. If I have a good Companion with me, I give him part on't: and after a while, to my Book again.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: But tell me now, upon the word of an honest Man; do you find none of those infirmities about ye, that are so common to Old Age?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Why truly, my Sleeps are not so Sound, neither is my Memory so firm as it has been. I have now acquitted my self of my Promise, to a Syllable; and told you the whole secret that has kept me Young so long. And pray'e let Polygamus deal as faithfully with us in the Relation of what has made him Old, so much Sooner.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: You are so much my Friends, that you shall have it without any Disguise or Reserve.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Pray'e let it be so then, and it shall never go further.

sp.speaker: POLYGAMUS,
sp.p: I need not tell you, how much I indulg'd my Appetite, when I was at Paris.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: We remember it very well: but hop'd, that upon quitting the place, you had left your Hot blood, and your loose Manners behind ye.

sp.speaker: Po.
Eu.
sp.p: What to your Fathers house?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Directly thither: But she past for the Wise of a certain Friend of mine, that in a short time was to follow
her.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: And did your Father swallow this?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Yes at first, but in a matter of four days he smelt out the Cheat: and then there was heavy work made on't. In this interim however I spent my time, and my Money in Taverns, Treating Houses, Gaming Ordinaries, and other extravagant Diversions of the like kind. In short; my • athers Rage was so implacable, He'd have no such Cackling Gossips he said under his Roof: He'd not own such a Rebellious wretch any longer for his Son, &c.) that in Conclusion, I was e'en fain to march off with my Pullet, and so Nestle in another place: Where she brought me a brood by the way.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: But where had you Money all this while?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Why, my Mother helpt me now and then by stealth: besides considerable Sums that I borrow'd.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And were there any such Fools as would give you Credit?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Why, there are those that will trust a Spend-thrist sooner then an honester Man.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Well! and what next?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: When my Friends saw my Father at last, upon the very point of Dis-inheriting me, they brought him to this Composition, that I should renounce the French Woman, and Marry one of our own Countrey.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Was she not your Wife?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: There had past some words in the Future Tense (as I will Marry ye, for the purpose) but then, to say the Truth, there follow'd Carnal Copulation, in the Present Tense, or so.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And how could you dissolve that Contract then?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Why, it came out afterwards, that my French Woman had a French Husband, only she was gone away from him.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: So that you have a Wife, it seems.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am now Marri'd to my Eighth Wife.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
The Eighth, do ye say? Why then he that gave you
the Name of Polygamus, was a Prophet. But they were all Barren perhaps.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: No, no, I have a Litter at Home, by every one of them.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: So many Hens with Eggs, in the stead of them, would be a happy Change. But you have enough of Wiving sure by this time.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: So much, that if my Eighth Wife should die to day, I'de take a ninth to morrow. Nay, 'tis hard, in my opinion, that a Man may not be allow'd as many Wives, as a Cock has Hens.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: 'Tis no wonder, at your rate of Whoreing and Drinking, to see you brought to a Skeleton, and an Old man before your Time. But who maintains your Family all this while?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Why, betwixt a small Estate that my Father left me, and my own hard Labour, I make a shift to keep Life and Soul together.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You have given over your Study then.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
I have e'en brought a N •
ble to Nine-pence; and all I have to trust to, is to make the best of a bad Game.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I wonder how thou hast been able to bear so many Mournings, and the loss of so many Wives.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I never lived a Widower above ten days, and the next Wife still blotted out the Memory of the last. I have given you here a very honest, and a true Abstract of my Life. I wish Pampirus here would but tell his Story as frankly as I have done mine. He bears his Age well enough, I perceive, and yet I take him to be two or three years my Senior.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I shall make no difficulty of that, if you can have Patience for so wild and Phantastical a Romance.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Never talk of Patience to hear, what we have a Mind to hear.

sp.speaker: PAMPIRVS,
sp.p:
I was no sooner return'd from Paris, but the good Old man my Father prest me
earnestly to enter into some Course of Life, that might probably advance my Fortune; and upon a full Consideration of the matter, it was concluded, I should betake my self to the business of a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I cannot but wonder, Why, that choice rather than any other.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why, I was naturally curious to know New things; to see several Countries, and famous Cities; to learn Languages, and to inform my self in the Customs, and Manners of Men. Now thought I, this is no way better to be compassed, then by Negotiation, and Commerce: besides a general understanding of things, that goes along with it.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Well! But Gold it self may be bought too dear.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: It may so, but to be short. My Father put a good Sum of Money into my hand to begin the World withal: Wish'd me good Luck with it, and gave me his Blessing. At the same time, he laid out for a Rich Wife for me, and pitch'd upon so Virtuous, and so Amiable a Creature; that she would have been a Fortune in her very Smock to any honest Man.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Well! But was it a Match at last?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No, for before ever I could get back again, Vse and Principal was all lost.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Wrack'd, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Wrack'd, we struck upon the what d'ye call the Rock?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: The Malta perchance; for that's a desperate Passage.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No, no; this is forty times worse. But it is somewhat like it however.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Do ye remember the Name of the Sea?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No, but it is a place infamous for a thousand Miscarriages. Pray, by your Leave: Is there a dangerous Rock they call ALEA? I don't know your Greek name fort't.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Mad Fool that thou wert!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
So, and what was my Father I
prethee; to trust a young Fop with such a gobb of Money! But it was in fine, the Rock ALEA Anglicé, The Devils Bones, that I was split upon.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: And what did you do next?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why, I began Providently to consider of a convenient Beam and Halter to hang my self.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Was your Father so implacable then? For such a loss might be made up again: and the first fault must be very foul, not to be Pardonable.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why you have Reason, perhaps. But in the mean while, the poor Man lost his pretty Mistress; for so soon as ever her Relations came to understand what they were to trust to, they resolv'd to have nothing more to do with me. Now I was in Love, you must know, over Head and Ears.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: In troth, I Pitty thee with all my heart. But what did you propose to your self after this?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Only to do as other people do in desperate Cases. My Father had cast me off; my Fortune was irrecoverably lost, and consequently my Wife: and the best Treatment I could get in the World, was to be pointed at, for a Debauche, squandring Sot. Without more words, it was e'en come to Cross or Pile, whether I should take up in a Cloyster or hang my self.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You were cruelly put to't. But I presume you had the Wit to pitch upon the easier Death of the two.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Or rather, the more painful; so Sick was I, even of Life it self.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: And yet many people cast themselves into Monasteries, as the most comfortable State of living.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Well! The first thing I did, was to put a little Money in my Pocket, and fly my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Whether went ye!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Into Ireland, and there was I made a Regular of that Order,
that wears Linnen above, and Woollen to the Skin-ward.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Did you spend your Winter there?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No, no, two Months only, and then for Scotland.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: How came it you staid no longer? Did you take Check at any thing?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The Discipline was not severe enough methought, for a Wretch that hanging it self would have been too good for.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And how went Matters with you in Scotland?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I e'en chang'd my Linnen Habit for a Leathern one, among the Carthusians.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: These are the Men that are in strictness of Profession, dead to the World.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: So methought, by their Singing.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Are the dead so merry then? But how many Months were you there?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Betwixt five and six.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: A strange Constancy, to hold so long in a mind!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You took no offence at any thing among the Carthusians, did ye?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I could not like so Lazy, a froward sort of Life. And then, what with Fumes, and Solitude, I phancy'd several of 'em to be Hotheaded: and for my part; having but little Sense already, I durst not stay, for fear of loosing the rest.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Whither did you take your next flight?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Into France: among those that give to understand by the Colour of their Habits, that they are Mourners in this World. I speak of the Benedictines: and of those particularly, that wear a kind of a Netted Hair-Cloth for their upper Garment.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: A terrible Mortification of the Flesh, I must Confess.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I was among them, eleven Months.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And how came you to leave 'em at last?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Why, I found they layd more stress upon Ceremonies, then True Piety. And then I was told that the Bernardines were a much more conscientious Order, and under a severer
Discipline: Those I mean that are Habited in White, instead of Black. I went and liv'd a matter of Ten Months among These too.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And what Dusgusted you here now?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I dislik'd nothing at all: For I found them very good Company. But I had an Old saying in my head: That such a Thing must either be done, or it must not be done: So that I was e'en Resolv'd, either to be a Monk in Perfection, or no Monk at all. I was told after this, that the Holiest Men upon the Face of the Earth, were those of the Order of St. Bridget. And these were the People that I thought to live and dye withal.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And how many Months were you with them, I beseech ye?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Neither Months nor Weeks; but in Truth almost Two Days.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: You were mightily fond sure of this kind of Life, to stay so long in't.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: They take no body in, you must know, but those that are presently profest, and I was not so mad yet, as to put my Neck into such a Noose, that it could never be got out again. And then the Singing of the Nuns, put me out of my Wits almost, with reminding me of my last Mistress.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Well! And what after this?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
My Heart was wholly set upon Religion, but yet upon this Ramble from one thing to another, I could not meet with any thing to my mind. But walking up and down afterwards, I fell into a Troop of Cross-Bearers. Some carry'd White Crosses; Others Red, Green, Party Colour'd, some Single, some Double, some Quadruple; and some again, several Sorts, and Forms of Crosses. I had a Reverence for the Christianity of the Memorial, but I was confounded,
which Form, or Colour, to make choice of, before another. So that for fear of the worst, I carry'd some of every sort. But upon the whole matter, I found there was a great difference betwixt the Figure of a Cross upon a Garment, and a Cross in the Heart. When I had Hunted my self weary, and never the nearer my Journies end; it came into my Head that a Pilgrimage to the Holy Land, would do my Work. For let a Man go to Ierusalem a very Devil he comes back a Saint.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: And thither you went then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Upon whose charge I prethee?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: That should have been your first Question. But you know the Old Proverb. A Man of Art will Live any where.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: And, what's your Art, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Palmistry.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Where did you serve your time to't?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What's that to the business?

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Under what Master?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The great Master of all Sciences; the Belly. In little; I set-up for a Fortune-Teller: And there did I lay about me, upon the Topique of things Past, Present, and to Come.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Upon good grounds, I hope.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: The Devil a bit that I knew of the matter: But I set a good Face on't, and ran no Risque neither: For I was paid still before hand.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: That ever so senseless an Imposture, should find a Man Bread.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
And yet so it is, that I maintain'd my self, and a Brace of Lacquies, very decently upon the Credit of it. Why, how should Knaves live, without a World of Fools of both Sexes to work upon? So soon as I got to Ierusalem, I put my self into the Train of a Rich Noble-Man, of about Seventy Years of Age, that could never
have Dy'd in Peace, he said, if he had not blest his Eyes with the sight of that Holy Place.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: He had no Wife, I hope to leave behind him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes, and six Children into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: A most Impious, Religious Old Man! But you came back I suppose, a Man of another World.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No, but to deal plainly with you, somewhat worse then I went.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: So that your Zeal for Religion was cool'd, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nay, on the contrary, hotter then e're it was. And therefore, I return'd into Italy, and apply'd my self to a Military Life.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: You sought for Religion in the Camp it seems: the most unlikely place under the Heavens, to find it in.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Ay, but it was a Holy War.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Against the Turks, perchance.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nay, a Holier War then that; or the Doctors were besides the Cushion.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: It was the War betwixt Iulius the Second, and the French. And then I had a phansie to a Souldiers Life, for the knowledge it gives a Man of the World.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: It brings a man to the knowledge of many things, that he had better be Ignorant of.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I found it so afterwards, And yet I suffer'd more hardship in the Field, then in the Cloyster.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Well and where were you next now?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why, I was thinking with my self, whether I should back again to the business of a Merchant, that I had laid aside; or press forward in the pursuit of Religion, that fled before me. While my thoughts were in this Ballance, it came into my mind, that I might do both under one.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: What? And set up for a Merchant, and a Monk▪ both together?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Well! And why not; What are
your
〈◊〉 , but a kind of Religious Traders? They flie over Sea and Land. They see, they hear every thing that passes: They enter into all Privacies; and the Doors of Kings, Noble-men, and Commoners, are all open to them.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Ay, but they do not deal for gain.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes, and with better success many times then we do.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Which of these Orders did you make choice of?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I try'd 'em all.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: And did none of 'em please you?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I lik'd them all well enough if I might but presently have enter'd upon Practice, and Commerce. But when I found, that I was to be slav'd a long time to my Offices in the Quire, before I could be qualified for the trust; I began then to cast about, how I might get to be made an Abbot. But said I to my self, Kissing goes by favour, and 'twill be a tedious Work; and so I quitted that thought too▪ After some Eight Years trifled away, in shifting from one thing to another thus, comes the News of my Fathers Death: So home I went; took my Mothers advice, Marry'd a Wife, and so to my first course of Traffique again.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: Well! And how did you behave your self, in your several shapes; for every New Habit, made you look like a New Creature.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why 'twas all no more to me, then the same Players Acting s • veral parts in the same Comedy.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: But be so Honest now, as to tell me, only which is the condition, in this Variety of Adventures, that is most to your liking?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: So many Men, so many minds. But to be free with you, that of a Merchant is most agreeable to my inclination.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
But yet there are great Hazzards and Inconveniencies
that attend it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: There are so; and 'tis the same Case in any other State of Life. But since this is my Lot, I'll make the best on't. Eusebius his turn is yet to come, and I hope he will not think much of obliging his Friends, in requital with some part of his History.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Nay, if you please, the whole Course of it is at your service.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: We shall most gladly hear it.

sp.speaker: EVSEBIVS.
sp.p: When I left Paris, It took me a Years time at Home to consider, what course of Life to settle in: And not without a strict Examination of my self, to what Study or Profession I stood most inclin'd. I was offer'd a good handsom Prebendary, as they call it: And I accepted it.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.p: That sort of Life has no great Reputation among the People.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: But, as the World went, it was to me very welcome. It was no small Providence, to have so many advantages fall into a Mans Mouth upon the suddain, as if they had been dropt from Heaven; as Dignity, Handsome Houses well furnish'd, a competent Revenue, a Worthy, and a Learned Society: And a Church at hand, to serve God in, when he pleases.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I was Scandaliz'd at the Luxury of the Place; the Infamy of their Concubines; and the strange Aversion those People had for Letters.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing to me, what others do, but what I do my self: And if I cannot mend the Bad, I chuse the best Company however, that I can get.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: And is this the condition that you have spent your whole time in?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: All but some Four Years, a long while ago, at Padua.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
And what did you
there?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I Studied Physick, a Year and half; and Divinity the rest.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: For the sake both of my Soul and Body; and that in both Cases I might be helpful to my Friends. I Preach't upon occasion too, according to my Talent. Under these circumstances, I have led a Life, easie and quiet enough: So well satisfied with one Benefice, that I did not so much as wish for any thing beyond it; and if another were offer'd me, I should refuse it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I wonder what's become of the rest of our Old Acquaintance, & Fellow Pensioners.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I could say somewhat of Them too, but we are just at the Towns End here: And if you please, we may be together in the same Inn, and talk o're the rest at leisure.
(Hugh a Wagoner,) How now Blinks. Where did you take up this Rubbish? (Harry a Wagoner.) And whither are you going with that Harlottry there?

sp.speaker: Hugh:
sp.p: You would do well to tumble the Old Fornicators into a Nettle-Bush, to bring 'em to an Itch again.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: And your Cattle want Cooling,

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: What do ye think of a Fair Toss into that Pool there, to lay their Concupiscence.

sp.speaker: Hugh▪
sp.p: I'm not us'd to those Gamboles.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: But 'tis not so long Sirrah, since I saw you throw half a Dozen Carthusians in the Dirt tho': And you like a Schellam, stood Grinning, and making sport at it when you had done, to see them Rise Black Carthusians, instead of White Ones.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: And they were well enough serv'd too: For they lay Snorting all the way like a Dead weight upon the Wagon.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: Well, and my People have been so good Company, that my Horses went the better for their Carriage. I would never desire a better Fare.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p:
And yet these are a sort of Men,
that you do not Naturally care for.

sp.speaker: Harry.
sp.p: They are the best Old Men that ever I met withal.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Harry:
sp.p: Because they made me Drink Lustily upon the way.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.p: An Excellent Recommendation to a Dutch Fore-Man.
